https://prez.dev/description.@value: The primary purpose for which a borehole was drilled or any secondary purpose that the borehole may acquire during its lifecycle. The vocabulary focuses on drilling purposes within the resources industry, with a focus on terminology as applied in the Geological Survey of Western Australia (GSWA) databases. Some terms covered by jurisdictional legislation are highlighted in the provenance field. Variations in terminology within definitions (i.e. usage of borehole, well and wellbore) stem from usage in different sectors of the resources industry, but for the purpose of this vocabulary are considered to be equivalent. In the context of this vocabulary, the term fluid energy refers to sources such as gas, petroleum and geothermal, as covered by the Petroleum Legislation Amendment Act 2024, and is exclusive of mineral sources of energy (e.g. coal, uranium).

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Drilling to assess the stability and conditions of rocks in the substrate prior to foundation and construction activities. This drilling aims to differentiate between solid basement and rock detached (floating) from the basement, as well as boring large holes deep into the ground in order to insert structures (e.g. piles, piers, or caissons) that are used to build a foundation for a construction project.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#hist.@value: Definition modified from Australian Drilling Industry Association (2020; The Drilling Manual, Sixth Edition) and https://blaze-equip.com/a-beginners-guide-to-foundation-drilling/.

https://prez.dev/description.@value: Drilling to assess the stability and conditions of rocks in the substrate prior to foundation and construction activities. This drilling aims to differentiate between solid basement and rock detached (floating) from the basement, as well as boring large holes deep into the ground in order to insert structures (e.g. piles, piers, or caissons) that are used to build a foundation for a construction project.
An exploratory borehole drilled to identify rock voids, and any other relevant changes in conditions of the earth before drilling, mining, tunnelling or construction commences.
